element_texts.text:
2
Grand trip across the plains — 
May Thurs. 19th, 1859
5 miles 
Crossed the Missouri a very muddy stream with a fast current containing a good deal of float wood
Omaha quite a city took sketch of the capitol camped on a small creek---feel fine--distance 5 miles
15" Fri 20th
Had an awful rain last night although I was in a tent but that leaked & you better believe we got a ducking.
Kate & the Snowden boys got washed out--camped on a small run Dis 10m
21" Sat 21st
Passed through Elkhorn a small dwarfish looking place rather squatty. crossed the Elkhorn river a stream hardly worthy the name. camped on its banks & prepared our fabric? -- saw a few indians one squaw had arms as large as my leg 6

May
3 
-37-Sunday 22d
Was the luck to lose my sketch book with several pictures in & other trinkets  passed paunee Village pop 3500 Indians it situated just below Fremont on the oposite side of the river (Platte) I stoped behind the train to purchace some moggasions one large 6 ft indian took my knife off of the my belt to look at it & would not give it up I pounch him & took it by main strength & being barefooted had to make use of my legs as they all (some 15 or more) took after me but I out ran them & lucky for me for what they would have done dont know. passed through Fremont only just staked out another facsimile of Elkhorn camped by a slough found a beautiful flower a species of the pea  Distance 16mi
Monday 23d
Very pleasant today met 34 teams of returning Pike’s Peakers Pikes Peak or bust Pikes Peak going & coming did you ever see the like

4
us boys invented a parady on the song Jordon
"I looked to the west & I looked to the east
& I spied the pikes peakers a comnig
some on horseback some on foot & some a running" &c
Camped on the Platte river Here we stand for the first time on the banks of the Platte Tis now sunsett & one of the most beautiful scenes I ever saw the sun appears to be sinking in the river pity the sun should dip in such a muddy stream-- the River is lined with beautiful shade trees --the river is shallow the bed is quicksand there seems to be no grade but the current is very rapid country very level except the distant sand hills 
took a bath this even in Platte Dis--20 mis
Tues 24th
77"
Still pleasant passed through Columbus a decent little town camped on the Platte got kicked head over heals trying 25 milk a wild cow wind raising some signs of a blow drove stakes & fassend our wagons & tents ready for it. Dis--20

May 
Wed 25th
89"
Cold cloudy & raining our blow came off & just sent things tents & such like but it didn't do us much harm camped away from the P. on our way to the crossing of Loupe fork couple of the boys had a fight-- hatchets drawn but nobody "kildt" still raining Dis 12
92" Thurs 26
Cold & raining started for a new camp drove 3 miles & stoped on Looking Glass creek in sight of Monroe--went hunting came to the Loupe Fork but no game here a few deer tracks & that's all went back & fished a little a splendid time herding cattle if a fellow only thought so Dis 3 mis
Fri 27th
99" passed through the city of Genoa a morman settlement had a grand old swim taking our cattle across current rather stiff had to wait half a day before we could get our wagons across on account of the crowd camped on the oposite side of Loupe F--. 7

May
120" Sat 28th
Camped in the woods last night -as we left the river we came [to] a poor [sandy] country - saw some antelope some of the company saw elk [wolves] & foxes tryed to kill an antelope but he would not stand camped on the bluff of the Loup fo 1/2 mile? unclear  went Elk hunting in the timber but got none took a swim in the Loup - i - Dis 21 miles??
Sun 29th
125
Went 10 miles after our oxen found them all right - camped unclear lay over till Monday after 5 mile drive took a good wash & swim in Loup -rained? this the evening Dis 5 miles
Mon - 30th
149"
This morning we formed ourselves into a company of wagons 21 men 5 women 4 children & 50 cattle Framed a code of by laws or constitution & by majority of vote Mr. Unclear Burr was elected captain - went antelope hunting got a splendid shot but my gun hung? fire & I lost my unclear unclear "unclear saw 174 antelope & 1 wolf camped on dry land 24

May
Tues 31st
165"
Cool & pleasant wind rather? high finaly we have reached the long wished?? for Prairie creek a clear & beautiful stream gracious what a good thing water is camped in a good place feel? good - took a bath - Dis - 16 -
Wed June 1st
185
Followed the Prairie?? creek several miles crossed over to wood river went hunting found an eagles next this country has been a great buffalo range on account of the buffalo chips found prickly pear a species of the cactus today?? camped on wood unclear 20
Thurs 2d
197"
Crossed the river run off the bridge broke an ex in the operation unloded?? chains into the wheel got some timber & made a new one passed through unclear a likely looking place for a year old?? Camped on the banks of Plath saw 30 or 40 buffalo we are oposite?? Ft Kearny?? or a mile above Dis 12 miles

June 8
201" Friday 3rd 
Myself with 2 others crossed the river twas cold  & windy & I never suffered more in my life in crossing one us Nate came near drowning - the south side of Platte? a hard looking hole alkali? & no feed? Uncle Sams boys looked quite spruce in their uniforms with their pop? guns a few cannon standing on wagons in the plaza was all I saw of note unclear unclear post office also - coming back had to throw away my unclear to keep from drowning lost my purse every cent I had in it & now I am straped & I am likely to be for months saw a dead squaw rolled up in a buffalo robe lying on the bank of Platte & lots of other curiosities camped on P- Distance 4 mi
211" Sat 4th
Took my gun & started for the buffalo saw one killed & afterwards had the luck of killing one myself that had been wounded in the leg a bull 21 unclear on his horn took a piece out of the hind leg & carried it to camp

9 June
[Twasnt?] tough nor any thing unclear
none of it was swallowed for all [we?]
chewed it - 1/2 hour some of our 
company have killed another and have
gone after it with 8 oxen PM - here
comes the buffalo he stands 7 ft high
head weighs 200 lbs when his breast bone
was split - he measures 14 1/2 ft from foot to foot
we skinned? him and took the best of the 
meat to jerk? drove on untill we
came to wood and jerked it saw thousands
of the buffalo in every direction unclear
227" Sunday S
Still day and pleasant - lots of
alkali? Prickely pears and c -- just unclear
a fellow that is barefooted and driving
loose cows and lame oxen -- camper? oer?
a nice creek took a swim in
a beaver's dam excellent spring water
feed unclear buffalo chips timber getting?
scarer we are quite a little ways
from Platte unclear 16-

June
Monday, 6th
236
Made an addition of 5 men in our 
company their cattle & wagons - drove 
9 miles camped (to bake as there is 
no wood for 200 miles above here)
on Buffalo Creek the same creek we 
unclear on last - had to feel of 
several heads as I am called our 
phrenologist, some i never saw before
as it was after dark so I had to go 
all by feeling they said I done it up 
right & all I saw was unclear good satisfaction
the earth dry & barren - Gis? (Is this his signature?)
Tuesday 7th
254
Pheasant drove to Platte Fort camped & took 
a swim & ran for 3 races & beat unclear
unclear of alkali - Gis?

Thurs 9th June [1894?]
.. left the river went over some sand 
hills came to [Paumee] Springs they look 
as beautiful a stream as large as a 
bucket from one besides several others 
close by not quite as large crossed two 
fine creeks camped on the banks of old Platte.
Dis 20
Fri 10th
9 miles to Black Mud Creek 14 miles 
to North Bluff North of Platte 6 rods

wide 12 inches deep clear as a crystal. 

No [wood] - camped, took a bath; 
had to watch tonight as it’s my 
turn perhaps the milk and biscuit 
didn’t suffer about 12 (o’clock). 
Dis 23 m 
Sat 11th
9 miles to Elk Creek a fine [spring] 
1/4 mile north of road 4 miles to Shepherds 
Creek 2 miles to Wolf Springs. 
Camped water very good.
Dis 15

Sun June 12th
332
Mild & pleasant laid over here until Monday took a swim washed my shirt had my head shaved to save the trouble of combing & for comfort - had a firm catch of mild green peas ()
3.3.2"
Mond 13th
Passed several creeks which were very clear & cold camped on Platter 3 miles this side of Rallesmake Rim on the opposite side of Platter are to be seen ridges of rock & cedars quite armantic for the season.
Dis 20
368"
Tues 14th
Had an awful time fighting cusquitoes last night built a smudge & drove myself out of the tent instead of the musquitoes.  Pattersons {  } in crossing a muddy creek in next the [} mile - the muddy mater head first one of their famled had a tall time getting out - camped on Platter had to go 5 miles ahead for the cows & after dark at that.
Dis 16

13    June

    Wed 15th

386
Passed ask Hollow crossed Castle river oposit A.H. Ask H is on the South side of Plalle a remarkable place in history  Camped on Plalle            Dis 18
406            Thurs 16th
Crossed a large creek at noon  passed over Land hills near indian { } Law an indian burying ground  A lot of skulls placed around in a circle all facing in Camped at the foot of Ancient bluff Ruins discovered 3 new flowers - my match is night.        Dis 26
424    Fri 17th
Visited the ruins they are about 300ft high or more [ ] them can be seen the Courthouse Rock, Chimney Rock & other memoriall things  Campers on Platter R. opposite  C. { } Rock  This rock is sightly named for it reminds on of a courthouse - even if knew and the name it is about 200 fat [  ].              Dis  18

14
June 
Saturday 18th
440
Opposite the Chimmey rock at noon took a sketch of it - camped on the Platte - Chimmey Rock is 6 miles from the [quad?] on the north side of R it is about 350 ft. high it is a curious piece of [unclear] I [unclear] at a distance looks like the work of man - 16 miles
45 6" Sun. 19th 
Took a sketch of the bluffs opposite an resemblance of [unlear] a Chinese wall & railway car platte full of Islands [camped?] on the platte opposite Scotts bluffs they are very imposing myself & others tried to cross over & see them we got halfway & backed out as the other side was a steep rock bank & probably we would get drowned 16
4th/ 4
Look a sketch of {sevths?} fluffs very pleasant rather warm camped on one plate under Rock{lapps]? first sight of the Laramie Peak - this.

Lost my memorandum book
went back over two miles + found it
we passed an Indian town to day
the Souix's they are the cleanest +
handsomist looking tribe I have seen
yet, almost feel in love with a beautiful
squaw of 16 summers or at least I
admired her unknown "witch of the Rockeys"
camped close by another indian town on
Platte the Sioux's have plenty of dogs
+ horses the dogs are half wolf + very
shy       Dis 20 m.
500 miles    Wed 22d
Camped on platte 8 miles below
Ft. Larimie The Black hills are just in
sight They are covered with cedars which
makes them appear black unknown only unknown
6 miles laid over unknown a letter home
Very pleasant -- Dis 6 miles
(unknown my match with Snowden we built a large
fire  got all the ox yokes I made a around it
took over blankets I went to unknown a grand looking unknown)

509              June

                    Thurs 23d

Drive past Ft. Laramie and camped to
Lay over in a bend of Platte  The P. has
become very crooked water deep & very
rapid current flowers ? had a good 
swim foliage very luxuriant.   Dis 9 m
528 

                   Fri 24th

One of the cows went back had to go back 
after her& before breakfast too, found her
back 9 miles didn't get hungry nor any
thing & as there were no teams near me
at noon  nor water either.  I drained
the old cows bag notwothstanding it was
the first milking (as she had a calf the day
previous) it was quite a boon which I 
enjoyed very much it probably resembled egg
nod or at least it reminds me of a story I have
heard my father relate " A neighbor had a "raising" &
invited all to help & as is customary eggnog was to
be furnished- The night before his cow has a calf & as he
came back a large beam was just on the point of falling he
set his bucket on a log & helped, some of the boys saw it

17 June
I mistook it for the regular [iggnod] gatherd themselves arround & [humals] for old [???] they "thot it wasent the best they had had" But then this is not coming to the point after noon I came to a spring road very hilly & rough in the black hills saw quartz plenty in ledges camped on the Platte oposite Larimie peak which is 8.800 ft high top perpetual snow on foot 38 mis Dis. 19
551 Sat 25
Forenoon hilly nooned at a beautiful spring from which I took a sketch of beautiful hill or mount above 
Afternoon Road level & sandy--camped on a Small creek Dis 28 m
561" Sunday 26th
Road good drove 10 miles camped on the platte till monday--went in swimming swam the Platte or "Hellespout" as you like it 3 others started with me one [flew?] out when half way over & landed a mile or so below I made land first & the furthest up stream a little tired

June 18
while the others drifted pretty well down now to get back was the rub for the other had but fun for me--Chattefield got in 3 [nods?] & [strangled?] as the mind was in his face & went back I got buck to camp with but little trader Nate also go back-- Chatt.. made an other trial got half way back went under I graded a log [I?] made double quick time for him arrived just in time to save his "bacon" the water here is very deep & awful current Very pleasant to day Dis 10 
583 Mon 24th
Roads very good to day some sand the hills are very curios in their formation to day they have the appearance of having been washed by the sea Clay rock very soft filled with bigger heads took a sketch of a rock which very much resembled a boy which we named Jonny america--Camped on Platte Dis. 22 miles

Tues June 28th.
Road rather crooked today-pleasant. Camped on Platte. Feed plenty. Dis 20. 
We’d 29th
Drove till noon. The strata was singular today. Saw my first life “horn toad”. Camped on Platte And in the afternoon set our tire’s hered the cattle on an Island. Took a good swim in the evening. Formed ourselves into a Lyceum and discussed this question “resolved that there is more pleasure or happiness in the pursuit than in the possession” Aff- gained a beat question for the next evening “Resolved that the love of money is greater than hvarfor moment” -still pleasant Dis 12 mi
Thurs 30th
Passed Cannon Ball ally and several other curiosities also an Indian town trading post and ferry saw some beautiful horses and ponies. Camped on the misgnitore. Mighty thick. Dis 20

July fri 1st
655
Passed the bridge which crosses the Platte I went across to see how things looked, a few government buildings + soldiers. several Indians and a tame antelope was all I could see --- plenty of stone coal in the unclear of the Platte --- The road forked took the hand or River road camped on The Platte this grandriver for the last time Dec 22.
Sat 2d
We bid adieu to the old Platte after 5 miles travel I have followed one river nearly 650 miles where the Platte enters the mountains the scenery is grandest I have yet seen the geological aspect is very curious here 11 miles more we passed Parson springs? Even the air here has a deleterious smell woven on a little creek almost dry to satisfy curiosity + on a bet as some paid me that not unclear unclear

July
677
I planted for a distant snow band on the summit of a mountain. I started on the rim? arrived after a ten mile walk much unclear we laid down on the snow + ate snow which revives me the funk was unclear + 2 unclear deep. a stream ran away as large as my arm the coldest + most delicious mates I have yet come across got a large snow fall + made for camp saw one or 2 Deer + an antelope arrived in camp at dusk with a piece of snow big as my little finger and I won my bet Camper at Willow Springs
692 Sun 3d
Drove 5 miles camped 2 hours on a small creek a gentleman has just died here with consumpation --- saw Horace Greely pass in a carriage but was not aware it was him at the time still I thot it was some by gum. Drove by Sweet Water river a  clear soft water streem camped on it unclear 15

707"
Mon - July 4th
Drove 5 miles to "Independence rock" Camped one hour a funeral in unclear before I arrived + after I left a wedding took place on the rock a grand foundation to get united on I had rather get married in the Devil's Gate - which is in sight - for there the water makes such a noise one could not hear the "ceremony" then if I did not like her could excuse myself on those grounds - took a sketch of I. rock turned a summersalt on the highest place in honor of old Uncle Sam - Camped 80 rods below the mouth of the Devil's Gate when I first entered it I was never so struck with astonishment huge rocks 400 ft upwards - water leaping from rock to rock here + there a a pine or cedar was seen which made the scene look splendifferous in evening I went through the gate to a dance at trading post. Girls mighty scarce - D's 15

707
July 
Tuesday 5th
I had the day all to myself while the rest set tire I took a picture from lower mouth of the cañon explored it put my name on the side of the gate went through + took a sketch from the upper end - went in swimming in the gate while naked I went up to the top 400 ft. crawled down to the brink + looked down men looked like a walking "Buffalo chip" for I could only see the hat
unclear
Wed 6th
My watch last night - as we were yoking up to leave a dog scared our wild unclear. When half yoked she jumped into the river + we kept her in she went up finaly broke loose from the yoke she went up stream + entered the Devil's gate where the water jumps around among the rock 2-40 on a spree. I got a rope + swam in to her lassoed her + she liked to have took.

me under- Camped on Sweet ? long tall mountains with snow on are seen now north of the river the "mount" are solid granite entirely naked south some timber and not so rocky at dusk we had a terrific thunder storm wind and rain first for a month ? our cattle to feed - Dr's 14? 
735 Thurs 4th Drove till nine crossed Sweet W. 3 times waited 2 or 3 hours for a mormon train to cross a bad place they have 6 or 7 yoke on each wagon freight of 500 lbs each driver has a whip that will fetch blood ever pop and they don't hesitate to use it either.Camping on sweet water? Alkals plenty feed midling? lots of dead cattle Dr 14

July, Saturday 9th. 
Forded S.W. twice and took dinner on its banks, found lots of strawberries picked among gooseberries and made a camp on strawberrie creek on our way to the summit of the rock. The distant hills present a curious view. 
Sun, 10th. 
From till noon camped to lay over till Monday. Wrote a long letter to Bro. Charlie. Oh how I wish he was with me, one of our boys since Burr. The shipment in with the Scott boys the water here in S.W. is very clear. 
Mon, 11th. From one mile crossed south W. for the last time - a post office here so I mailed my letter. Passed the summit of the rock-up which appeared like a prairie in Wis. Last one of the day camped below Pacific Springs, a very large one surrounding here. I drink the waters of the Pacific for the first time.

813
July
Tuesday 12th
Here I am on the highest summit I ever was yet. 9000 ft high can look all over the country can trace the road (?) for miles each way can see no less than 25 trains and some has 50 wagons 5 yoke each started at 11:00 camped on little paudy having been straped for a month or so was relieved by finding a $5.00 gold piece while hunting in the red dirt and gravel for gold as it looks like gold being dirt according to allaccouels (?) feed very porr Dis. 14
835
Wed 13th
Left dry Sandy at 11:00 20 miles to big Dandy no water no feed dry Sandy and dusty - Big Sandy a clear handsome strem camped on it no wood came near having a fight with Edd Patterson he carried his gun with him all the time here or else he'd get whaled feed poor or not any

July, Thursday 14th. 
Followed B.S. 8 miles from it and camped on it by a trading post. No feed pots, our lame ox for $20.00 met. I had a talk with Mr. Joist an eastern correspondent. Got some information. 
Friday, 15th.

July
Sunday 17th
Drove 11 miles ate on Hamsfork. Here lies the ruins of a mormon-massacre cattle by hundreds the air being so pure and light here on the mountains the dead attle are all whole hair and all some have been stood up in an erect position by the boys I was guilty of doing so myself there is by the way (?) here a chain 1/2 mile long having been hooked together by some of the boys The irons of 45 or more wagons are scattered arroud the wood work being front for fire wood there was a simular sigh on Big Sandy but smaller drove late camped below the junction of Mud Creek Fork with Hamsfork which we have crossed 4 times today. 
Mon 18th
Drove one mile camped to lay just above the small town of Millersville a large store or trading post blacksmith shop and c a carorral made of wagons

July. 
Over 900 majors and all large ones which cost in the States over $200.00 each and used by Russel & Co. to carry freight to St. Lake or rather Ft. Bridges. This field made by standing nay, is full of cattle. I stood here 2 miniature and a picture of Millersville for $5.00 with which I bought me a pair of shoes having been barefooted 600 mieles or so. Thot I'd try shoes - feel good. Dis. 1 mile  929"     Tues 19th"  Took dinner one mile East of Fort Bridges. Ft. B. is a very pleasant place fertile & well timbered & the best of water soldiers look well Camped 10 miles this side of Ft. B. at the foot of a very steep & long hill one of the worst on the plains feed & water very good excellent soil - Dis. 22 -  950  Wed 20th" This is the most beautiful country I have seen yet in the afternoon I left the road & went into the

July 30

mountain it excelled any place I have yet seen for flowers & beautiful trees
I would like to live here saw 15 or 20 beautiful
flowers & c just befor me came into camp
she had a thunder shower - it fell in sheets
the hardest I ever saw in 15 minutes torrents
were running down the mountain like
rivers of lava it was flat where we 
hauled up but the water was running a
foot deep all over the ground after the
rain we drove to a little valley where
there was good feed & as it happened
one of the best springs in the country
was there which made a beautiful camping 
ground ground very fertile Dis. -21-
Drow
962                Thurs 21st
Drove 10 miles & roomed 1 mile from
Bear River - Crossed B.R. it is clear 
as a chrystal cold & filled with laye pebble
stones, 18 inches is the depth of the water
its banks were completely lined with good 
Strawberries I did not go to the Far

31      July
Springs but saw some of the tar from
think it is a very good location for
wagons - drove through a small cañon
camped on a small creek - Dis 12
g80     Fri 22d
Drove over the mountain crosses Echo 
Creek entered Echo Cañon which is
rightly named took sketches one of Cave
rock the other of the Urn & Cave Castle
both see in one view camped right in the
cañon & went hunting saw lots of deer
tracks but killed nothing currents & 
whortle berries by the bushel     Dis.      18
-               Sat 23d

                     "

Laid over to hunt deer & gather 
berries saw some deer but killed none
had a grand time climbing mountains & 
eating berries Wrote a long letter to Dear
Sister Mattie Water & feel good -
had a grand supper -
"999"-       Sun 24th

                           "

Passed through the most fearful part
of the cañon - here are fortifications

built on both sides large deep trenches dug across the canon. This is the work of the Mormons. They thot they had got Uncle Sam but luckily he found another route 12 miles to the end of canon. Here it opens to the Webber River which empties into the Great S Lake.  Crossed  track? up a canon leading to the summit of the mountain here was plenty of  illegible. Mon 25th  Still in the canon saw several Indians and 2 trading posts. Entered the main canon a large creek in it which we had to cross 18 times. Camped 1/2 mile from where we leave the canon to ascend the mount.  Scott boys broke a wheel - bought our feed or pasture from the Mormons - Tues 26th Here the creek had been dammed by the Mormons + more fortifications - we had to go 4 1/2 miles up a very steep  ?that reached the summit at noon. here can be seen the immense valley of Salt Lake

mountains covered with snow in all directions. here comes the descent hitched our cattle once behind locked all the wheels fasined a long rope to the top of wagon to keep it from ending over which I hung on to like a tiger or dog at a root got down safe nobody killed camped 10 miles from the Great city any amount of orries currents exceeding large saw a handsome young lady at a hotel here she was crossing the plains in a carriage
Wed 27th Ascended the last mountain descended through the canon to the famous G S L City where we arrives at 1:00 P.M. A very different city from what I had imagined it to be. Camped in the street one block west of Main St. and front of Franklin's (one of the 12 apostles) house some of our boys talk of selling out.  Finished my letter to Mattie.
Thurs 28th Laid over till noon during forenoon I took a sketch of Brigham's Mansion

It is constructed of doby brick and in or around his block there is a wall built of cement and pebble rock 12 ft high. The temple is not yet built but commenced. That also had a wall around it. Having obtained admittance to see B. Y. - which none of our train did but me - I went in. He has lots of clerks all armed to the teeth.  Old B. Y. had his Sharp's rifle and telescope and was about to go hunting.  I took a pencil sketch of him.  Train concluded to stay all day I had to herd cattle in afternoon.  Took a bath in the river Jordon where B. Y. wash the sins from his people - 
Fri 29th Our company has split all to smash. 17 of the boys going to go in the passenger train sold their cattle and weapons I took Nate's picture in the "apostles house" at noon bid adieu to G. S. L. City. The city has a wall nearly around it. The water comes from the snow in the mountains and is conducted in a shallow stone ditch through

35 July
every street in the city & around each block has 10 acres divided into 8 lots thus diagram each one has an acre & 1/4 on which they raise enough to keep them. 2 miles from city we came to warm springs where they have erected a bath house a beautiful stage unclear from the city & springs - called - "The Queen of the mountains" Two miles from the first spring is another hotter one in the afternoon  I made the acquaintance of an artist Jms. R Key with Landers Ex & being a little on that line of business myself such as an excellent trime? and exchanged sketches camped below Centerville a small city excellent farming land Dis? - 10 1055
Sat 30
Passed through Centerville camped in Frmington got some of our oxen shod Traded one or 2 oxen for fresh ones There is a large spring feed middling Dis 8 1045
Sun 31st
Last night we had 2 thunder showere & it was my watch at that  took dinner at the Prairie house  Prickely Pears plenty  Camped on the bank of Webber R Dis 20

August
10 of 1   Monday 1st     36 p
Crossed [W   ] Riv went through the thriving city of Ogden saw a specimen of Mormon sculpturing  here crossed Ogden River on a bridge tole 50cts passed mormon Fort one of B.Y. defeners - ate dinner West of North Ogden or Ogden hole  after dinner we caught [two] frogs which we served up at supper  in PM passed a cold spring close by a hot one.  camped by a reservoir for irrigating gardens  it is 25 rods in diameter nearly round & 25 ft deep  very clear & cold  had a good swim in Even   frogs meal fine - Dis. 16
1081  Tues 2d
Pulled out at noon during forenoon  took a sketch of the pond last night one of our company was robbed  he staid at Salt Lake 2 days & then came on horseback traveled in the night was stoped & demanded money or life  he had but 40 dollars   another of our boys was robbed of $20.00 while in Slt Lake  camped 2 miles from the Lake 
Dis 10

Aug
37
110.0     Wed 3d
Drove through Box Elder or Brighams city passed several nice springs nooned ½ mile from St. Lake - I waded in 3/4 of a mile but no swim  [ twant ] knee deep  crossed warm salt river 2 miles from Bear river camped on B.R.  Musquetoes awful  smoke won't affect them.   Some talk of enlarging our overhang as a great Indian massacre took place 60 miles ahead [Shep....]  train robbed & killed they have brought their spoil down to sell to the mormons    Dis 19
1111
Thurs 4th
Drove to ferry swam our cattle toll $2.00 per wagon  3 miles to the Malade R.  crossed on a bridge one ox fell off the bridge we cut the yoke & let him "drop" - it was a narrow escape scared the women in the wagon camped on the side of the mountain by the last valley spring formed a new company consisting of 23 wagons & [ ] - till danger is past feed poor but good water    Dis. 11

Aug
1141    Friday 5th       38
4 miles to warm Springs  14 miles Blue spring  Water lukewarm & salty   12 miles to Hensells Spring a large one on the mountain side   arrived here at 10.00 P.M.  commenced today to take a map of the road sketched a rock that resembled a mans head  Dis 30
1153    Sat. 6th 
Crossed Deep creek at 11 AM  nature by accident made a ford a stone ledge  crossing the creek at right angles below and above tis deep  the creek is deeper than wide over my head but I could jump it   nooned at the falls & took a bath there camps where the creek is above the level of the land & begins to over flow its banks [ spread ] & sinks  feed good         Dis 12
1168    Sun 7th
Laid over till noon - I watched last evening   Arrived at lone spring at sundown - drove until 9 AC  no water nor feed   awful night we had with the cattle    Dis 15

39  Aug
1190      Mon 8th
Drove 9 miles to Stony creek  S.C. is a very beautiful stream clear & cold its source is in sight a huge snow bank just on the Mtn above  took a small sketch of its source also a [ _olf ] for Charles B.  lost one of my pencils  drove on to DeCasnie Creek a clear cold stream  15 ft wide  18 in deep camped here  the landscape beautiful   Dis 22
1205            Tues 9th

     Awful cold last night - crossed DeC  c 3 times  an attack from he indians was expected last night  mooned on De.C. c  5 miles to the junction of Lublets cutoff & Salt lake road -  took 3 or 4 sketches to day   the Cily rock looks quite romantic camped in a valley by a small creek there are about 3000 head of cattle in this valley  tonight great fear of the indians is entertained    Dis 15

1217    Wed 10th
crossed 2 creeks enter the ca[n]on gained the summit of Goose creek mountains where we met  over

200 hungry Soldiers bound for Camp Floyd from the [ Summit ] can  he has an extensive view of the county  we are so high that mountain after mount. secede as far as the eye can see  started down the mountain it is the worst descent on the trip  ["Trip tare smarte to bring" ] finally we found ourselves on Goose creek  dusty tired & hungry a late dinner  -  drove 2 miles camped & killed a beef which was readily disposed of among the Emigrants good living now - we sometimes camp in the neighborhood of a dead ox if the wind's right its quite pleasant if a fellow didn't care what he said  Goose Creek not extra clear    Dis. 12
1229           Thurs 11th
Follower up G.C.  Crossed 2 or 3 times  formed our wagons & tents in a coral in case of an attack from Indians  Camp on G.Cr had some fresh [ clams ] for supper
There are 2 or 3 trains here  my watch tonight    Dis 12.
1247            Fri 12
Left G. Cr. followed up one of its branches through the ca[n]on here the rock present a beautiful appearance

The Statue rocks are grand one resembles the bust of H. Clay one of a female in an artistic "posish" one of a lion one of an eagle  they are all in a row - nooned at the leaving of the branch Charlie B the artist is with me today
Camped at rock springs a lazy stream filled with fishes [     ]  [   ]   Dis 18
1259      Sat 13th
The country very barren in sight of the Humboldt range   passed cold & Alkali springs  Camped by the wells in Thousand spring Valley    Dis 12
1275       Sun 14th
Drove to deep spring & nooned   feed good - had a sad joke played on me here which was hard to take  "3 of us were going to herd cattle as I went to jump the creek one of them stepped on my whip  I lit flat in the mud which was 18 in deep"  drove to hot springs can boil eggs here  there are several springs quite a creek runs from them & in 10 rods it joins a cold creek both together are about 110º - just right for bathing  had a good one   Dis. 16

16 miles
Aug. Mon. 15th
1 mile crossed cold creek 2 miles we came to Mt. Spring Creek which we followed 2 its source and nooned there - drove to fork in road took the right hand the left hand is harder in the spring during high water camped on the head waters of Marys or Humboldt river camp good wood scarce my watch 2 night awful cold. 
18 miles Tues 16th
Followed down the [canyon] creek through the most grotesque looking hole I ever was in awful unclear -indale in here are some large warm springs 120 degrees the pond an awful mud hole our horse got in and had to be pulled out he got in all over  we nooned on canon creek. drove on 9 miles some dusty camped on creek water clear and cold  feed the best we have had

Wed 17th
The nights are awful cold there being so much snow on the Humboldt range just East of us 15 miles drove miles and the Humboldt river is is not as large as Canon Creek here we crossed the river and camped on the famous Humboldt and it is one of the handsomest rivers I ever saw
20 miles Thurs 18th
Dusty and no rain fish are plenty but I can't catch any of them. Camped on the Humboldt passed the lightning and rain. 
Fri 19th
Went in swiming and a fishing with Charley B. was with him all day and last night
Sat 20th
Drove cattle and day camped with the lightning and rain on Humboldt. I take a bath in the river every day. 
15 miles Sat 20th
Entered the [canon[canyon]]  the scenery very beautiful crossed the river 4 times and made a regular S and came out safe

work one sketch ate dinner where small cr. joins the Humboldt crossed Cold cr. and 7 or 8 small creeks beautiful streams filled with large trout can see them swimming around camped on the Humboldt where the road leaves the river had a swim with a Shushone indian bought me a uniform cap
Sun 21st
Laid over ibid plenty of ShushoneI took a picture of one and had a good swim
21 miles Mon 22d
Left the river went into the mountains killed a big buck Hare  nooned by a spring of good water, drove to gravely ford crossed went down a mile and camped feed scarce
15 miles Tues 23rd 
Passed the stage at 10 A.M. stopped and wrote home catched up in time to get dinner in P.M. went over 4 awful bluffs then hunted a new ford and crossed the river

The winter of 1858 for financial reasons I had to get a Country School to teach I found one in Elk Grove Wis. I passed Exam and got a boarding place a mile from the S. house I had a path across lots one morning the snow had blown across my path and suddenly I found myself in the bottom of a lead well Prospect lead wells were plenty through that region near 15 ft deep my only hope was a small penknife I commenced to dig steps on oposite sides and it took nearly an hour to get out I was nearly frozen when I reached the School I could not have been heard had I yelled for help pupils were waiting for me I caught a bad cold and

46
it settled on my lungs and before spring I was spitting blood I had heard it said if one lived out doors they would never die of Consumption I heard that a neighbour 2 miles away was going to go to Cal. in a Prairie Schooner I went to him and asked what he would board me for and I would walk across the plain he said $50.00 I handed him the gold, he said he would start the next week I packed a large valise and took a small light rifle and started with him Mr Burr and his Brotherinlaw Mr. Chattfield and wife and Mrs Burr and a girl of 6 or 7 & a boy of 4 yrs   7 of us the women and children rode we had a folding table and a fly tent at night I

47
wrapt a blanket around me and laid on the table the rest slept in the wagons and another tent they had two wagons, skooners. As my Diary did not commence till we crossed the Missouri Riv I will note some incidents we crossed the Miss. Riv at Dubuque and camped on a hill by a nunnery or Catholic inst and started for Cedar Rapids roads very muddy sometimes they doubled up  then from C. Rapids we went thro Tama to the capitol of Iowa Desmoines seemed a fine city as we went thro it when we reached Lewis I stopped part of a day to visit 3 step bros and their families and caught up with the wagons and before I reached Council Bluffs I visited a Step Sister I had not seen since I was 10 yrs old in Ohio

48 July 2nd /23
Dear Mr. E.E. Ayer
I am sending this memorandum Book to day, you 
will observe I left the Platte July 2nd and  I have not seen it since I see
by the map there is a R. Road from 
Salt-Lake down the Humboldt River
and across the desert  to Truckee Riv.
I hope to go that route some day
My daughter Mrs. Geo. W Maher had 
this book and she wants it returned
to her, you can have a typewriter 
make a copy- when I was 16 I was
very spry I could turn a summersault as
good as a circus man and was the champion
runner and wrestler at the academy
this accounted for my encounter with
the Indian

49
I was born April 3rd 1840 my health is better now than any time since the Civil War and I hope to pass the 100 mark. I had no forebear pass to my father died of heart failure in his 66th year. One born before had the same heart failure at 69 so I invented heart exercise as I had a few years ago a weak heart that pained me when gas came up my gullet and have invented a system of exercise for the body alone for that is the machine. Yours truly, A. F. Brooks 424 Warwick Rd. Kenilworth, Ill.

50
I do not remember why I did not keep this diary longer I think it was because we started on our trip across the Desert or else I ran out of ink I think it was about 40 or 50 miles we took water along to drink we came to a pool of hot water near the middle of desert the clearest I ever saw just like the purist glass or diamond could see the bottom 15 or 20 feet it was unfit to  drink or give to the oxen when we came in sight of Truckee River Capt. Burr ordered all of the teams unyoked they immediately stampeded for the River + all plunged in, it was a great sight we climed a small mountain to get a view of Pyramid Lake a grand sight- The next day or the day after, I bade 
the company good bye crawled into a stage + was soon in Cal. at Eureka after I washed + had dinner I took a dishpan + went prospecting clawing up dirt + gravel + washing it in the brook I worked 2 hours or so took my find back + sold it for $3.50 soon after I went to Orleans Flat + did a little mining I then went to Nevada Cal. staid a while + there I came

to Grass Valley- I worked in a mine until I nearly got killed blasting I then painted my first oil picture an Indian killing a Bear + raffled it off for $75.00 a drug store man won it + hung it in his store . I was giving a carpenter lessons in drawing, one day he said he had a house to build + wanted to get a carpenter to help. I said, hire me, he took down a saw + a piece of scantling + said saw it in two I did it quickly he brot? his little steel square + found I had it square both ways he said all right + I will give you 50 unclear more than the usual price so I got a little experience at that, I next took up interior decoration + paper hanging I painted a half life portrait + had a run of 20 portraits. The war came I got a letter from my Bro. Charlie stating that he had enlisted +  my 2 other Bros had also enlisted also stating our two Grandfathers were both in the Revolution War + that Father was in the war of 1812. When I got money enough I came to my boyhood home in Ohio got engaged + enlisted in 105th O.V.I + was in 3 yrs rec'd 3 wounds two of them bone wounds

Ever since the first portrat proj corner of page torn off trace around a shadow on the wall. Parts corner of page torn off painting has been one of the first arts in a unclear of a unclear - parble the oldest work I have by early Egyptians unclear were all in profile with front view of the body I have seen - this part is strikethrough, unclear text above some very good heads were shown about at the unclear _ at Pompain and the Museum at unclear. I saw some very good heads in unclear - dist--ful but portrait painting did not make much advance with oil painting was discovered in Germany and Abbot Dover probably made the best head in his time and Leonardo NaVinci rivaled all in his Mona Lisi which he worked on 4 years he was a great artist in expression and unclear ink blot was great in color and elegance of pose _ then came the four great portrait painters  unclear word above 400 years ago about the time of discovery of the same place on and other place another as the the first I have also rated them thus unclear word above Rembrandt
